choices.text: Methionine synthase, magnesium, ATP7B
Glutamyl aminopeptidase, magnesium, ATP7A
Lysyl hydroxylase, copper, ATP7B

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with characteristic kinky hair and growth retardation, and after thorough investigation, he is diagnosed with Menkes syndrome. Considering the enzymatic and genetic background of this disorder, which enzyme and cofactor are likely to be deficient, and what gene is typically mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lysyl oxidase and copper             

 

Option D: 

 

  • Menkes syndrome, characterized by kinky hair and growth retardation, results from a dietary deficiency of copper, an essential cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase that functions in formation of the covalent cross-links that strengthen collagen fibers.
  • Defects in ATP7A result in Menkes disease

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methionine synthase, magnesium, ATP7B: Methionine synthase requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor, not magnesium. ATP7B mutations are associated with Wilson's disease, not Menkes syndrome.

 

Option B. Glutamyl aminopeptidase, magnesium, ATP7A: Glutamyl aminopeptidase does not typically require magnesium as a cofactor, and ATP7A is associated with copper transport, not magnesium.

 

Option C. Lysyl hydroxylase, copper, ATP7B: While lysyl hydroxylase is a copper-dependent enzyme, mutations in ATP7B cause Wilson's disease, which is different from Menkes syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menkes syndrome is a disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to a deficiency in copper absorption and transport. Copper is a necessary cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase, which is critical for the formation and maintenance of connective tissues. A deficiency in lysyl oxidase activity due to inadequate copper levels results in the characteristic clinical manifestations of Menkes syndrome.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 281,631

questions.text: A middle-aged male working in an industrial setting presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, loss of appetite, abdominal pain, and poorly coordinated movements. He undergoes an eye examination, which reveals the findings depicted in the provided image. Based on these symptoms and eye findings, which gene is most likely mutated in this condition, and which mineral would be appropriate to administer as part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ATP7B gene and zinc

 

Option A: 

 

The clinical presentation described is consistent with Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration). The eye finding mentioned would likely be a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a golden-brown ring around the cornea due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane.

 

Wilson's disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase that:

  • Is primarily expressed in the liver
  • Is responsible for copper excretion into bile
  • Facilitates incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin

 

When this gene is mutated:

  • Copper cannot be properly excreted from the liver into bile
  • Copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin is impaired (leading to low serum ceruloplasmin)
  • Copper accumulates in the liver, brain, cornea, and other tissues

 

Treatment includes:

  1. Chelating agents (D-penicillamine, trientine) to promote urinary copper excretion
  2. Zinc therapy, which induces intestinal metallothionein production that binds copper and prevents its absorption
  3. Dietary restriction of copper-rich foods (shellfish, nuts, chocolate, mushrooms)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. ATP7A gene and zinc: Mutations in the ATP7A gene cause Menkes disease, not Wilson's disease, which is characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and deterioration of the nervous system. Zinc is not the treatment for Menkes disease; instead, early copper-histidine injections are sometimes used.

 

Option C. ATP7A gene and magnesium: As mentioned, mutations in the ATP7A gene lead to Menkes disease. Magnesium is not related to the treatment of either Wilson's or Menkes disease, and there's no known link between the ATP7A gene and magnesium supplementation.

 

Option D. ATP7B gene and selenium: While the ATP7B gene is associated with Wilson's disease, selenium supplementation is not a treatment for this condition. Selenium is more commonly associated with antioxidant properties and thyroid function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. Clinical manifestations include hepatic dysfunction, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea. Treatment involves copper chelation therapy with drugs like D-penicillamine and zinc supplementation which reduces intestinal copper absorption. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent irreversible organ damage.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/ed: p 521.

choices.text: Menke’s kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child is evaluated in an outpatient department in India after experiencing two episodes of generalized seizures three days prior, along with noted developmental delays. Upon examination, the child has a fair complexion, easily breakable and sparse hair, and limb hypotonia. Microscopic examination of the hair reveals a twisted structure. His serum copper levels are low, as are serum ceruloplasmin levels. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Menke’s kinky hair syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • Here dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract and cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene).
  • Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells and other tissue cells → accumulation of copper inside the cell and not available for metabolism → defective cross-linking of connective tissue (affecting vascular and connective tissues).
  • The affected child dies in infancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acrodermatitis enteropathica: 

In Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, zinc absorption is defective and is characterized by acrodermatitis, diarrhoea, alopecia, ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Selenosis: Selenium toxicity is called Selenosis causing hair loss, falling of nails, diarrhoea, weight loss and garlicky odour in breath.

 

Option D. Manganese Deficiency: Deficiency of manganese leads to impaired growth and skeletal deformities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menkes kinky hair syndrome, also known as Menkes disease, is a disorder of copper transport that leads to a deficiency of copper throughout the body. It is characterized by sparse and kinky hair, hypotonia, developmental delay, and failure to thrive. The low levels of serum copper and serum ceruloplasmin support the diagnosis.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p522.

choices.text: Low tissue copper
Low serum iron

questions.text: A 3-year-old child in India is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of poor growth and low muscle tone. The most striking physical feature is the presence of unruly, "kinky" hair. Additionally, the child exhibits increased joint laxity and thin skin. Given these clinical findings, which of the following laboratory findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low tissue copper

 

Option B:

 

  • This child’s kinky hair is a symptom of Menke disease, where there is an alteration in a copper-binding ATPase → storage of copper in cells and prevents its normal absorption from the intestine.
  • Enzymes which uses copper as cofactor can modify and degrade amino acids in collagen → connective tissue symptoms (lax joints, thin skin) in Menke disease.
  • Wilson disease is also caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High ceruloplasmin: Ceruloplasmin, the major copper transporter in serum, is decreased in both diseases.

 

Option C, Option D: Copper is necessary for iron absorption and incorporation of iron into haemoglobin. In Wilson disease, high serum copper → high serum iron and saturation of transferrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

kinky hair, low muscle tone (hypotonia), and poor growth, suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, a genetic disorder affecting copper levels in the body. One of the hallmarks of Menkes disease is low levels of copper in various tissues due to defective copper transport.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 521.
